You often bring up a quote from the former president saying that politics need not be mean and nasty.

Because politics has - have become mean and nasty in a way that I never thought I would see in recent years.
And we all see it.

Well, Chairman Ryan's proposal does decrease the deficit, but what's important is not only decreasing the deficit but how we do it.
And if you look at his plan, he has no contribution from revenue at all.
He extends tax cuts that average over $125,000 a year for millionaires and then turns around and says that we have to eviscerate the safety net for the lowest income people in the country.
He has cuts in low-income programs that are so massive that over two-thirds of the multitrillion-dollar cuts in his budget come from programs targeted on Americans with low or moderate incomes.
We'd have the biggest transfer of income from the bottom to the top, and the biggest increases in poverty and inequality as a result of any piece of legislation in modern American history.
I am firmly convinced and committed to the need for long-term deficit reduction, but it needs to be done in a balanced and equitable way, not something that takes us back to the gilded age.
Some say a tradeoff, and this has been discussed in various proposals that have been argued around.
A tradeoff might be if Democrats can accept some changes in Social Security in exchange for Republicans accepting some changes in tax rates.
Well, we do need to make changes in both places, but in Social Security, there's a debate there too.

Many Republicans feel that all of the changes to restore long-term Social Security solvency should be made by cutting benefits, even though the typical Social Security beneficiary only has household income of about 21,000 a year, and the average benefit for retirees is only about 14,000 a year.
I'm kind of in the middle on a lot of these issues.

I think that in Social Security, we need to restore long-term solvency, which would also contribute modestly, not hugely, to deficit reduction by having a balanced plan that comes half from trimming future benefits and half from raising more revenue for Social Security.

And for the budget as a whole, I believe that we ought to achieve a balanced plan to deal with long-term deficits that, again, is about half on the budget cut side and about half on the revenue side with the revenues including significant changes in tax breaks, tax expenditures, tax entitlements, as Alan Greenspan once called them.

And it's interesting that Ronald Reagan's former chief economic adviser, the noted conservative economist Martin Feldstein, wrote last summer that if you want to cut wasteful spending, the biggest source of wasteful spending in the federal budget and the first place to go to cut wasteful spending are all these subsidies that are delivered through the tax code.
So I think if we could have a balanced, a 50-50 mix for the budget as a whole and for Social Security, both sides would have to compromise, but that would lead us to a balanced, long-term plan.
Would the changes in Social Security include an increase in the retirement age?
I personally would rather get the contribution on the benefit side and Social Security in another way.
And the reason I say that - raising the retirement age is widely misunderstood.
Most Americans who hear it think that what it means is that if you continue to work till 67 or 68 or 70, your benefits would be the same.
That's not accurate.
An increase in the retirement age is simply an across-the-broad cut in Social Security benefits.
Whether you begin to draw benefits at 62, 65, 67 or 70, the effect is the same for each year that the so-called full retirement age and the Social Security benefit formula is raised.
No matter what age you retire at, your benefits are cut seven percent.
Now, I'm not a hardliner who would say if there's any change in the retirement age, the whole plan should be rejected.
I'm not saying that.
I just think that there are better ways to design the contribution on the benefit side.
Should...
If one does raise the retirement age, one needs to have very carefully designed - and it's hard to do - offsetting mechanisms to shield lower-income people who really can't work longer from hardship.
Well, as you mentioned, Social Security is not insignificant, but it's not the heart of the deficit reduction problem, and that goes to the question of health care and Medicare and Medicaid.
So if the privatization plan for Medicare is not - that's advocated by Congressman Ryan - if that's not the solution, what is?
Well, let's - there are two issues about Ryan's plan.
I think it's inherently unwise to simply throw all the seniors into the private insurance market and say: Here's a fixed amount of money.
Go buy insurance.

It'll be very hard to do develop the regulations necessary and to enforce them to the degree necessary to ensure the older, sicker frail seniors whom insurance companies don't want because they cost more, would actually be able to get coverage.
There's lots of ways for insurers to design their provider networks and benefit packages to discourage sicker people, really frail people.
But the second issue is whether you favor the privatization approach or not, there's the question of how much would this private voucher purchase?
It isn't the privatization, per se, that produces the big cuts in the Ryan Medicare proposals.
It's the fact that the vouchers he would provide people to go buy private coverage would not keep pace with health care and, over time, would cover less and less and less of health insurance.
So...
Or they could be indexed, as was suggested yesterday.
But in any case...
And those numbers are stark.
Colorado has one of the highest suicide rates in the U.S.
Guns account for half of those suicides.
And if you look at all firearm deaths in Colorado, nearly 80 percent of them are suicides.
Hydrostatic.
No, no, no, no. This is key.
This is key, Neal.

The whole point - the Congressional Budget Office issued a study yesterday of Ryan's proposal, and they said he - because he only indexes them for regular inflation rather than health care costs, they said that by 2030, seniors on Medicare, instead of paying 25 to 30 percent of the costs to their health care out of their own pockets, as under the current structure, would pay 68 percent of the costs out of their own pockets.
If you make $200,000 a year, that's fine.
If you're an elderly widow living on 15,000 a year, it's not.
So what would I do, is really your question.
Mm-hmm.
There's no question, but that the single most important thing we have to do for the long term is to reduce the rate of growth of health care costs.

But it's critical to understand that Medicare and Medicaid costs for beneficiary for 30 years have merely been rising at the same rate as health care costs for beneficiary in the private sector and throughout the U.S.
health care system.

Experts generally agree that if you artificially try and whack(ph) Medicare and Medicaid without slowing the growth of health care's cost in the system as a whole, what you'll end up with is a two-tier system, rationing by income.
The people on Medicare and Medicaid don't get full coverage.
So that that takes us to the question of how do we transform the U.S.
health care system to not rise so fast in cost?
Now, the Affordable Care Act, the health reform law, has a number of pilots, demonstrations, comparative effectiveness research to learn more about how to do that.
We did most of the things we now know how to do on that front in the health reform law, but they're way short of what we ultimately need to do.

So we need to aggressively move forward on the pilots and the demos on comparative effectiveness research to find expensive treatments that don't work or are no more effective than less-costly treatments.
And we need to be able to implement those findings in Medicare and Medicaid as the results come forward.

Unfortunately, one part of Chairman Ryan's plan would actually repeal the independent Medicare advisory board that is charged with looking at the research and recommending ways to slow cost growth in Medicare and beyond.

Now, I think there are some changes we can make in the next few years, without waiting, that we know how to do now in Medicare, particularly in the prices it pays for pharmaceuticals, which Chairman Ryan doesn't support.
They're closer to the pharmaceutical industry, but the Democrats don't support, either, because of lobbying from the pharmaceutical industry.
There are some things we can do now, but they are modest compared to what we have to do long term.
So where that takes me is, in the long run, the biggest savings need to come from health care.
And some are from Social Security, but in neither case are those going to deliver big savings in the next 10 years.
Both parties say we're not changing Social Security for current retirees.
Even Ryan's plan has very little in the way of Medicare savings in the next 10 years.
So what do we do?
What I would recommend - and it's similar to what the Reagan economics adviser Martin Feldstein has recommended, and former Obama budget director Peter Orzag, as well.
At the end of 2012, let's let all of the Bush tax cuts expire on schedule, not just those for people over 250,000 a year.
The economy did great in the 1990s with the tax rates we had then, under the Clinton administration.
The top tax rate of 39.6 percent is still way below the 50 and 70 percent levels of the '50s, '60s and '70s.

If we do that along with the changes we can make now in health care, savings in discretionary spending, closing some tax loopholes, reforming farm price support programs and the like, then in a reasonable period of time, we can get the deficit low enough to keep the debt from rising faster than the economy.
That buys us time for stage two, which is the big enchilada, which is reforming how the entire U.S.
health care system delivers and pays for health care, and creating incentives to stop over-utilizing ineffective or less-effective-but-expensive treatments.
And...

And then, for the decades after the next decade, a particular emphasis has to be placed on getting savings in Medicare and Medicaid as a result of slowing the growth of health care costs in the entire U.S.
health care system, which would be good for employers and workers, as well.
